description: Repeated successful login for user susan.gregory from 192.168.128.170 using PLAIN method; possible credential misuse.
Identical repeated login for susan.gregory from the same IP; likely duplicate of previous event.
Repeated login for damian.jordan from the same IP using weak authentication (PLAIN); potential compromised account.
Duplicate entry of damian.jordan login; same timestamp and details as previous event.
Another duplicate log of damian.jordan login; repetition in multiple log files suggests monitoring redundancy.
New login session for susan.gregory, reusing same source IP and credentials; may indicate session persistence or stolen credentials.
Same login as above stored in mail.log; redundant but not anomalous by itself.
Redundant logging of previously flagged susan.gregory login; no new indication of additional activity.
Authentication success for michael.davis from source IP matching local IP; low anomaly but may indicate lateral movement or persistence.
Same login for michael.davis recorded again, likely due to system-level log duplication.
Successful IMAP login using PLAIN method, which may indicate unauthorized use of valid credentials.
Repeated IMAP login by same user from same IP, suggesting possible credential misuse or persistence tactic.
Continued login by same account and IP, consistent with automated or persistent access attempts.
Suricata flagged TLS traffic with invalid records; this may indicate non-standard encrypted communication or obfuscation.
Invalid TLS handshake message to internal host; may indicate probing or crafted TLS-based attacks.
Invalid TLS handshake message detected; potential for evading security monitoring or using custom encrypted C2 channel. JA3 hash indicates uncommon client fingerprint.
Invalid TLS record or malformed traffic observed, which may indicate use of non-standard TLS or obfuscation to avoid IDS detection. Matches same session as previous invalid handshake alert.
Duplicate log of previously detected invalid handshake; confirms Suricata identified it across systems (Snort format).
Repeated invalid TLS record/traffic with unique JA3 signature; possible C2 beaconing or obfuscated exfiltration to external host (in.hotjar.com).
Snort-format alert for invalid TLS handshake, mirrors Suricata detection against same destination; likely correlated C2 activity.
TLS traffic detected with invalid records, which could indicate encrypted traffic misuse or evasion techniques
Invalid TLS handshake message observed; this may point to attempts to bypass protocol validation or non-standard communication
TLS invalid record alert on encrypted channel, suggesting potentially obfuscated malicious communication
Incoming TLS connection with invalid handshake message from external IP, may be scanning or malformed traffic
Successful IMAP login over TLS detected, could indicate credential usage or persistence via valid accounts
Repeated successful logins with different usernames suggest use of valid accounts possibly for lateral movement or persistence
Login from same user observed earlier, could indicate persistent access via valid credentials
SSH daemon received a connection attempt without identification string, consistent with scanning or probing behavior
Incomplete SSH connection suggests probing or enumeration of open ports and SSH services
SSH server reports a connection without client identification string; pattern is consistent with lateral scan
SSH daemon received a connection without proper identification string, indicating a scan or automated enumeration of SSH service.
403 response for base HTTP GET request may indicate probing for web application access or enumeration.
SURICATA flagged an invalid SMTP reply, suggesting a malformed or non-standard interaction with the SMTP service.
Client attempted to access a restricted directory on the web server, indicating likely reconnaissance or misconfiguration testing.
403 error from a GET request to a known nmap-checking endpoint, with Nmap Scripting Engine user-agentâ€”typical of automated scanning.
403 POST request to /sdk with Nmap user-agent shows automated probing of potentially vulnerable endpoints.
Access attempt to forbidden directory suggests scanning or misconfiguration probing.
Access attempt to directory associated with Nmap check endpoint, indicating scan activity.
WPScan probing specific plugin path; HEAD request with WPScan user-agent confirms plugin enumeration attempt.
Multiple HEAD requests to plugin paths using WPScan user-agent strongly suggest automated WordPress enumeration.
The user agent 'WPScan' indicates automated scanning for vulnerable WordPress plugins; the targeted plugin 'click-to-chat-for-whatsapp' is commonly probed for known vulnerabilities.
Scanner is checking for existence of the 'cloudflare' plugin, often associated with previous vulnerabilities. Repeated 404s and WPScan user agent suggest a reconnaissance scan.
Request for 'cloudflare-flexible-ssl' plugin using WPScan agent indicates probing for plugin-specific exploits; part of a broader reconnaissance activity.
Multiple HEAD requests in rapid succession to various WordPress plugin directories from the same IP using WPScan indicate an automated scan to enumerate plugin vulnerabilities.
Attempt to access 'bing-webmaster-tools' plugin path, combined with WPScan user agent, suggests enumeration of vulnerable or outdated plugins.
A single request to a known WordPress plugin directory using WPScan indicates targeted plugin enumeration activity.
Multiple HEAD requests for different WordPress plugin paths in rapid succession using WPScan suggests automated vulnerability scanning.
Request to a WordPress plugin directory using WPScan; repetition with other entries confirms pattern of reconnaissance.
Multiple 404 HEAD requests in quick succession for a wide range of plugin paths points to systematic probing by WPScan.
Continued probing of various WordPress plugins by same IP in same pattern using WPScan clearly indicates automated reconnaissance.
Request to a known vulnerable WordPress plugin directory using WPScan user agent indicates reconnaissance for vulnerable plugins.
Request to attachment_id parameter using WPScan user agent, likely testing for known WordPress vulnerabilities in media attachments.
Attempt to access 'wp-config.php-' suggests attacker is probing for misconfigured or backup WordPress configuration files.
Repeated probing using 'attachment_id' suggests media enumeration attempts on WordPress via WPScan.
Legitimate IMAP login was detected; repeated successful logins could be sign of compromised credentials.
Access to non-existent directory '/academics' without referrer suggests directory fuzzing or brute-force scanning.
Attempt to access 'access-log.1' indicates possible effort to find exposed log files for sensitive information.
High frequency of 404 errors from same IP in a short timeframe indicates automated scanning for web paths.
Request for '/accountants' among a sequence of 404s suggests fuzzing for valid endpoints.
Access attempt to '/advancedsearch' fits into a broader pattern of endpoint fuzzing to discover hidden or admin functionality.
Multiple 404 errors targeting various common web paths indicate automated scanning to discover valid application endpoints.
404 on /beheer suggests probe for admin or backend panel using non-English (Dutch) common endpoint, part of broader scan.
Probe to access /wp-admin/user/webcalendar suggests enumeration of WordPress admin plugins or outdated components.
404 for /wp-admin/user/webcart indicates attempts to discover e-commerce plugins or CMS misconfigurations.
Access attempt to .htpasswd file under WordPress plugin directory indicates an effort to access sensitive auth configuration.
Request to author.dll within FrontPage extensions directory is indicative of old vulnerability scanning for legacy exploits.
Attempt to access internal WordPress editor theme assets suggests scanning for plugin enumeration or LFI vectors.
Multiple 404 errors for slight variations in WordPress resource names suggest automated path fuzzing to find valid files.
Repeated 404 errors on unusual WordPress paths such as 'zh_TW' in the tinymce plugin path suggest an automated scanner probing for known plugin or language pack vulnerabilities.
Another probe on a non-existent WordPress tinymce path ('zones'), likely part of an automated reconnaissance activity targeting known or guessed plugin directories.
Repeated successful IMAP logins from the same IP and user suggest a potential use of valid credentials post-compromise.
Identical login activity to a previous event; logged from a different log source (mail.log). Still indicates suspicious repeated logins.
Same login event duplicated in syslog, suggesting multi-log source detection. No change in threat level.
New login instance shortly after the previous ones, same user and IP. Indicates persistence via valid credentials.
Same login as previous but logged in different file. Continues pattern of suspicious persistence behavior.
Another duplicate log event from a third log source. Indicates log correlation across systems.
Authentication success by a different user (damian.jordan) from a new IP. Pattern of account logins consistent with potential credential misuse.
HTTP anomaly: SURICATA unable to match response to request. Could indicate malformed HTTP traffic for obfuscation or evasion.
Snort alert matches SURICATA anomaly: protocol decode failure. Likely non-standard HTTP traffic to bypass detection.
Authentication success by a different user (john.hammond) from a separate IP. Consistent with pattern of compromised account usage.
TLS invalid handshake message from external IP (54.217.59.35) to internal system; could indicate malformed or crafted packets used for evasion or reconnaissance
Suricata alert for TLS invalid record/traffic suggests malformed TLS stream or potential evasion technique targeting 192.168.128.4 from 54.217.59.35
Successful IMAP login for user susan.gregory; repeated successful authentications (348 times) may suggest compromised credentials or scripted persistence
Authentication failure for user christopher.friedman on dovecot from local IP 192.168.128.195; matches signature for password guessing
TLS handshake failure from 3.33.220.150 using known malformed JA3 fingerprint targeting 192.168.128.4; similar to TLS evasion patterns
Internal IP 192.168.128.4 generated TLS invalid handshake to 3.219.152.16; may indicate misconfigured or probing client software
TLS record anomaly from external IP 94.245.192.25 (akamaized CDN domain) to internal client; likely benign CDN issue or misparsed traffic
Internal IP 192.168.128.4 sent invalid TLS traffic to feed.theplatform.com; could be client-side TLS stack issue or corrupted packets
Duplicate log of TLS invalid handshake from internal client to external streaming site feed.theplatform.com; possible misconfiguration
Another duplicate TLS anomaly (same timestamp); repetition supports assumption of benign misconfiguration or library mismatch
User 'www' changed UID to 'phopkins', which could represent lateral movement or privilege abuse if not expected behavior.
Login session opened for user 'phopkins' by UID 33 (www-data), which may indicate use of a service account for privilege escalation.
Session opened for user 'phopkins' by UID 0 (root), suggesting root initiated the session possibly to run processes as another user.
User 'phopkins' used sudo to execute a command as root, indicating a legitimate or malicious privilege elevation attempt.
Session opened for root by root suggests a sudo session was initiated; typical of privilege escalation events.
Session closed for root; informational message showing end of sudo session, not directly indicative of malicious behavior.
User 'phopkins' used sudo to recursively list the /root directory, likely probing sensitive areas.
User 'phopkins' used sudo to read /etc/shadow, an action typically used to access password hashes.
Root session opened via sudo indicates escalation; this is a standard part of sudo activity.
Session closed for user root. Routine event marking end of sudo session, no attack pattern inferred.
